Initial commit of US Ignite competition single-page site

This is a single-page Jekyll site intended for use with GitHub Pages
or another Jekyll host, like CloudCannon.

The page is primarily styled with [Tachyons] classes, which have been
customized through [tachyons-custom] with PostCSS variables. The
browser-ready tachyons.min.css is built via tachyons-cli and must be
committed to the repo. A minimal number of additional custom styles
are defined in css/main.scss, using Jekyll's built-in Sass support.

Most of the content is statically defined (with CloudCannon-
compatible "editable" classes where appropriate), but the information
about judges and mentors is managed through two corresponding Jekyll
Collections in _judges and _mentors.

[Tachyons]: http://tachyons.io
[tachyons-custom]: https://github.com/tachyons-css/tachyons-custom

commit_list.message: Fix README link and update gemspec description
commit_list.repo_description: On-demand rendering of Jekyll pages

commit_list.message:
Add `jekyll preview` command to render pages on demand

Adds a `preview` subcommand to Jekyll via its commands API (which uses
Mercenary). `jekyll preview` is similar to `jekyll serve`, but instead
of rendering the whole site by default every time the command is
called, it doesn't render anything until a request is made, and then
it only renders the requested page.

This is accomplished in two parts: first, extending Jekyll's existing
Serve command (and it's internal 'Servlet') to pass the current URL
path to Jekyll's Regenerator (part of the existing incremental
regeneration feature), and then extending Regenerator to tell Jekyll
that it should only render and write the file matching the URL.

This approach has the advantage of relying largely on Jekyll's already
tested features. Notably, the stages of Jekyll's build process prior
to render still function on the whole site, so pages that rely on data
loaded from other files (like an index of blog posts) should still
render correctly.

At the moment this is a very alpha release; it's only really been
tested with a default `jekyll new` site. It also calls the build
command from start to finish for every request, though it's probable
that it could at least cache the Site instance rather than create a
new one for every request, and possible that it could perform the
earlier build stages (like read) only once.

commit_list.repo_description: Shared workflows and best practices (draft)

commit_list.message:
Create initial drafts of Git workflow, configuration, and ProTips

These docs define a developer-specific Git and GitHub workflow,
excluding GitHub practices that might also apply to a more general
audience, such as around issues, labels, and so on.

I aimed to link to supporting documentation as much as possible both
to avoid repeating what is well-documented elsewhere and to generally
indicate some of the origin and reasoning behind these practices.

Though I didn't link directly to any other Git styleguides (I wanted
to avoid introducing confusion if/when our own guidelines diverge),
I also referred to these:

* https://github.com/thoughtbot/guides/blob/master/protocol/git
* https://github.com/alphagov/styleguides/blob/master/git.md

In general, these are draft specifications intended to allow
interested teams to hit the ground running. If a more robust
governance process comes later, my hope is that these might act as
as a useful starting point.

Merge pull request #12 from cityofaustin/api

Create an AWS Lambda function to trigger gh-pages updates
commit_list.repo_description: A shared GitHub Pages site for content from multiple repos

commit_list.message:
Create an AWS Lambda function to trigger gh-pages updates

The previous deploy.sh script worked fine, but setting up a GitHub
webhook to trigger CircleCI builds directly from submodule
repos presented a problem, since it's not possible to only trigger a
webhook/build on changes to the submodule master branch (GitHub's push
event fires on every push).

This solution implements a webhook receiver "API" that runs on AWS
Lambda and API Gateway, and filters and translates the webhooks before
effectively proxying the request to CircleCI. As a consequence, the
deploy.sh script that runs on Circle is now much "smarter": it updates
only the affected submodule, rather than all of them, and it includes
a GitHub-compatible link to the commit in the source repo right in the
gh-pages commit.

This was my first time doing much of anything with Lambda, so there
were a lot of lessons learned, which I might cover in more depth in a
blog post or more general documentations. For now, some highlights:

* Lambda doesn't support env variables, which rules out the typical
  12-factor secret storage. The solution: use Amazon's KMS service to
  encrypt the secrets, which can then be safely stored directly in
  the repo (even if it's public). I used an npm package called
  [Cryptex][] to help.

* There is a wide variety of dev/deploy tools for Lambda functions. I
  looked at Claudia, Gordon, and Serverless, and used Claudia for
  initial deployment and testing, but found those options lacking in
  one way or another. I went with the decidedly more-verbose, less-
  magical, and wonderfully predictable [Terraform][], which is a more
  general purpose tool and might seem like overkill, but I think it's
  great. The Lambda function that Terraform uploads is created by
  [node-lambda][], via `npm run pack`.

[Cryptex]: http://technologyadvice.github.io/lock-up-your-customer-accounts-give-away-the-key/
[Terraform]: https://www.terraform.io
[node-lambda]: https://github.com/motdotla/node-lambda

commit_list.message:
Add CircleCI configuration and deploy script (resolves #9)

Sets us up to use CircleCI to automatically update the gh-pages branch
with the latest submodules when a submodule repo webhook kicks off a
build. The gh-pages commits updating the submodule SHAs are written by
@quesobot, our new GitHub robot.

(@quesobot has been granted write access to this repo, and a personal
access token with `public_repo` scope is set to QUESOBOT_ACCESS_TOKEN
in CirceCI.)

At the moment, GitHub will fire a submodule repo webhook for every
push event, including on non-master branches, so we may implement a
webhook middleman (probably an AWS Lambda function) to avoid
unnecessary builds.

commit_list.message:
Customize recursive navigation to support multiple micro-sites

Effectively an opinionated version of the generic recursive navigation
in the previous commit. The key difference is the introduction of a
"toc_level" (Table of Contents level), a front-matter property that
configures the URL-level at which "micro-sites" (i.e. individual
Guides and Projects) exist. Each micro-site gets its own header and
persistent, fully expanded navigation.

commit_list.message:
Show generic recursive navigation proof-of-concept

Implements a pure-Liquid recursive navigation tree, as described in
navlist.html. This version is meant to be generic, so for instance it
always renders all root pages (siblings of /). The actual
requirements for our City of Austin Pages use case are more specific
(see subsequent commits for details), but I figured I'd commit the
initial proof-of-concept for posterity.

Simplify navigation logic by supporting Jekyll collections
commit_list.repo_description: https://cityofaustin.github.io/digital-services-engagement-guide/

commit_list.message:
Simplify navigation logic by supporting Jekyll collections

The previous iteration of the recursive navigation partials included
a lot of complexity related to the notion of a "toc_level," which
essentially defined the level at which we wanted to render sub-
navigation as opposed to global navigation. That originally came from
wanting high-level separation between Guides and Projects (and
corresponding submodules), but we've now switched to simply having
separate sites for projects and guides, so that complexity isn't
required.

We've also moved all the projects and guides from submodules into
combined repos, so it makes more sense now to configure them as
Jekyll collections rather than dumb folders. This has particular
advantages in editors like Siteleaf, where the editor-facing
navigation is organized by collection.

Zilker's navigation can thus be simplified from the two-part `nav`
and `navlist` partials to one `sidenav` partial, which is then called
to generate both the global navigation (from `site.pages`) and each
collection's sub-navigation. The default layout decides which nav to
show based on `page.collection`, which means that a "collection
index" page (i.e. the one linked to from the global navigation) need
only define `collection` in its front-matter in order to show the
collection sub-navigation.

The new partial eschews some of the logic of the previous version
(like filtering child pages before recursing) with the goal of being
generally simpler to understand.

This commit also adds an example collection and a couple example
pages to use when developing the theme.
commit_list.repo_description: https://cityofaustin.github.io/digital-services-engagement-guide/

commit_list.message:
Merge pull request #4 from cityofaustin/gem

Allow theme to be installed as a gem
commit_list.repo_description: https://cityofaustin.github.io/digital-services-engagement-guide/

commit_list.message:
Allow theme to be installed as a gem

I avoided this in the first place because GitHub Pages hosting doesn't
support using custom gem themes, and I would have liked for our
default theme to be GH-pages compatible. But I've since realized that
the alternative of having all the theme files in a repo that we clone
when we want to create a new site has perhaps even more downside, in
terms of confusion both maintaining the theme itself and attempting to
apply updates to downstream repos via git merge.

This means we won't be able to use GitHub Pages hosting without at
least some kind of intermediary, like Siteleaf, but I think it will
make the overall setup much easier to grok.

commit_list.repo_description: A work-in-progress Jekyll theme for City websites on GitHub Pages.

commit_list.message:
Simplify navigation logic by supporting Jekyll collections

The previous iteration of the recursive navigation partials included
a lot of complexity related to the notion of a "toc_level," which
essentially defined the level at which we wanted to render sub-
navigation as opposed to global navigation. That originally came from
wanting high-level separation between Guides and Projects (and
corresponding submodules), but we've now switched to simply having
separate sites for projects and guides, so that complexity isn't
required.

We've also moved all the projects and guides from submodules into
combined repos, so it makes more sense now to configure them as
Jekyll collections rather than dumb folders. This has particular
advantages in editors like Siteleaf, where the editor-facing
navigation is organized by collection.

Zilker's navigation can thus be simplified from the two-part `nav`
and `navlist` partials to one `sidenav` partial, which is then called
to generate both the global navigation (from `site.pages`) and each
collection's sub-navigation. The default layout decides which nav to
show based on `page.collection`, which means that a "collection
index" page (i.e. the one linked to from the global navigation) need
only define `collection` in its front-matter in order to show the
collection sub-navigation.

The new partial eschews some of the logic of the previous version
(like filtering child pages before recursing) with the goal of being
generally simpler to understand.

This commit also adds an example collection and a couple example
pages to use when developing the theme.

commit_list.repo_description: A work-in-progress Jekyll theme for City websites on GitHub Pages.

commit_list.message:
Create an AWS Lambda function to trigger gh-pages updates

The previous deploy.sh script worked fine, but setting up a GitHub
webhook to trigger CircleCI builds directly from submodule
repos presented a problem, since it's not possible to only trigger a
webhook/build on changes to the submodule master branch (GitHub's push
event fires on every push).

This solution implements a webhook receiver "API" that runs on AWS
Lambda and API Gateway, and filters and translates the webhooks before
effectively proxying the request to CircleCI. As a consequence, the
deploy.sh script that runs on Circle is now much "smarter": it updates
only the affected submodule, rather than all of them, and it includes
a GitHub-compatible link to the commit in the source repo right in the
gh-pages commit.

This was my first time doing much of anything with Lambda, so there
were a lot of lessons learned, which I might cover in more depth in a
blog post or more general documentations. For now, some highlights:

* Lambda doesn't support env variables, which rules out the typical
  12-factor secret storage. The solution: use Amazon's KMS service to
  encrypt the secrets, which can then be safely stored directly in
  the repo (even if it's public). I used an npm package called
  [Cryptex][] to help.

* There is a wide variety of dev/deploy tools for Lambda functions. I
  looked at Claudia, Gordon, and Serverless, and used Claudia for
  initial deployment and testing, but found those options lacking in
  one way or another. I went with the decidedly more-verbose, less-
  magical, and wonderfully predictable [Terraform][], which is a more
  general purpose tool and might seem like overkill, but I think it's
  great. The Lambda function that Terraform uploads is created by
  [node-lambda][], via `npm run pack`.

[Cryptex]: http://technologyadvice.github.io/lock-up-your-customer-accounts-give-away-the-key/
[Terraform]: https://www.terraform.io
[node-lambda]: https://github.com/motdotla/node-lambda

commit_list.message:
Allow theme to be installed as a gem

I avoided this in the first place because GitHub Pages hosting doesn't
support using custom gem themes, and I would have liked for our
default theme to be GH-pages compatible. But I've since realized that
the alternative of having all the theme files in a repo that we clone
when we want to create a new site has perhaps even more downside, in
terms of confusion both maintaining the theme itself and attempting to
apply updates to downstream repos via git merge.

This means we won't be able to use GitHub Pages hosting without at
least some kind of intermediary, like Siteleaf, but I think it will
make the overall setup much easier to grok.

Merge pull request #5 from cityofaustin/collections

Simplify navigation logic by supporting Jekyll collections

Simplify navigation logic by supporting Jekyll collections

The previous iteration of the recursive navigation partials included
a lot of complexity related to the notion of a "toc_level," which
essentially defined the level at which we wanted to render sub-
navigation as opposed to global navigation. That originally came from
wanting high-level separation between Guides and Projects (and
corresponding submodules), but we've now switched to simply having
separate sites for projects and guides, so that complexity isn't
required.

We've also moved all the projects and guides from submodules into
combined repos, so it makes more sense now to configure them as
Jekyll collections rather than dumb folders. This has particular
advantages in editors like Siteleaf, where the editor-facing
navigation is organized by collection.

Zilker's navigation can thus be simplified from the two-part `nav`
and `navlist` partials to one `sidenav` partial, which is then called
to generate both the global navigation (from `site.pages`) and each
collection's sub-navigation. The default layout decides which nav to
show based on `page.collection`, which means that a "collection
index" page (i.e. the one linked to from the global navigation) need
only define `collection` in its front-matter in order to show the
collection sub-navigation.

The new partial eschews some of the logic of the previous version
(like filtering child pages before recursing) with the goal of being
generally simpler to understand.

This commit also adds an example collection and a couple example
pages to use when developing the theme.

Merge pull request #4 from cityofaustin/gem

Allow theme to be installed as a gem

Allow theme to be installed as a gem

I avoided this in the first place because GitHub Pages hosting doesn't
support using custom gem themes, and I would have liked for our
default theme to be GH-pages compatible. But I've since realized that
the alternative of having all the theme files in a repo that we clone
when we want to create a new site has perhaps even more downside, in
terms of confusion both maintaining the theme itself and attempting to
apply updates to downstream repos via git merge.

This means we won't be able to use GitHub Pages hosting without at
least some kind of intermediary, like Siteleaf, but I think it will
make the overall setup much easier to grok.

Merge pull request #12 from cityofaustin/api

Create an AWS Lambda function to trigger gh-pages updates

Create an AWS Lambda function to trigger gh-pages updates

The previous deploy.sh script worked fine, but setting up a GitHub
webhook to trigger CircleCI builds directly from submodule
repos presented a problem, since it's not possible to only trigger a
webhook/build on changes to the submodule master branch (GitHub's push
event fires on every push).

This solution implements a webhook receiver "API" that runs on AWS
Lambda and API Gateway, and filters and translates the webhooks before
effectively proxying the request to CircleCI. As a consequence, the
deploy.sh script that runs on Circle is now much "smarter": it updates
only the affected submodule, rather than all of them, and it includes
a GitHub-compatible link to the commit in the source repo right in the
gh-pages commit.

This was my first time doing much of anything with Lambda, so there
were a lot of lessons learned, which I might cover in more depth in a
blog post or more general documentations. For now, some highlights:

* Lambda doesn't support env variables, which rules out the typical
  12-factor secret storage. The solution: use Amazon's KMS service to
  encrypt the secrets, which can then be safely stored directly in
  the repo (even if it's public). I used an npm package called
  [Cryptex][] to help.

* There is a wide variety of dev/deploy tools for Lambda functions. I
  looked at Claudia, Gordon, and Serverless, and used Claudia for
  initial deployment and testing, but found those options lacking in
  one way or another. I went with the decidedly more-verbose, less-
  magical, and wonderfully predictable [Terraform][], which is a more
  general purpose tool and might seem like overkill, but I think it's
  great. The Lambda function that Terraform uploads is created by
  [node-lambda][], via `npm run pack`.

[Cryptex]: http://technologyadvice.github.io/lock-up-your-customer-accounts-give-away-the-key/
[Terraform]: https://www.terraform.io
[node-lambda]: https://github.com/motdotla/node-lambda

At the moment, GitHub will fire a submodule repo webhook for every
push event, including on non-master branches, so we may implement a
webhook middleman (probably an AWS Lambda function) to avoid
unnecessary builds.

Merge pull request #1 from cityofaustin/navigation

Navigation
Render navbar and sidenav separately (via capture variables)

Customize recursive navigation to support multiple micro-sites

Effectively an opinionated version of the generic recursive navigation
in the previous commit. The key difference is the introduction of a
"toc_level" (Table of Contents level), a front-matter property that
configures the URL-level at which "micro-sites" (i.e. individual
Guides and Projects) exist. Each micro-site gets its own header and
persistent, fully expanded navigation.

Show generic recursive navigation proof-of-concept

Implements a pure-Liquid recursive navigation tree, as described in
navlist.html. This version is meant to be generic, so for instance it
always renders all root pages (siblings of /). The actual
requirements for our City of Austin Pages use case are more specific
(see subsequent commits for details), but I figured I'd commit the
initial proof-of-concept for posterity.

commit_list.repo_description: Workflow and best practices guides maintained by the City's Innovation teams.

commit_list.message:
Create initial drafts of Git workflow, configuration, and ProTips

These docs define a developer-specific Git and GitHub workflow,
excluding GitHub practices that might also apply to a more general
audience, such as around issues, labels, and so on.

I aimed to link to supporting documentation as much as possible both
to avoid repeating what is well-documented elsewhere and to generally
indicate some of the origin and reasoning behind these practices.

Though I didn't link directly to any other Git styleguides (I wanted
to avoid introducing confusion if/when our own guidelines diverge),
I also referred to these:

* https://github.com/thoughtbot/guides/blob/master/protocol/git
* https://github.com/alphagov/styleguides/blob/master/git.md

In general, these are draft specifications intended to allow
interested teams to hit the ground running. If a more robust
governance process comes later, my hope is that these might act as
as a useful starting point.

commit_list.repo_description: The Austin Convention Center (ACC) and Palmer Events Center (PEC) websites.

commit_list.message:
Add a simple rake task to trigger nightly site rebuilds via Heroku

Intended as the simplest possible way to trigger a rebuild of the
both sites each night, which needs to happen to ensure the Calendar
stays up-to-date even if updates aren't made via GitHub or Contentful
in the current month.

It's obviously a somewhat naive solution, but the risks of failure
are fairly low, and low-cost even if they do happen. As the City
invests resources in building out more static-site infrastructure,
it's possible (even probable) that this will be replaced by something
a little more robust (e.g. with error handling, and perhaps using
Lambda w/ Cloudwatch events instead of Heroku Scheduler).

commit_list.message:
Add Contact Sales form to the Book an Event page template

* Uses and mostly doesn't modify the USWDS form styles. Implements
  semantic types (email, date) and attributes (required) to maximize
  browser-specific form features (like Chrome's validation and date
  picker).

* The form is relayed to email via FormSpree, to an email address
  specificied in the site-specific YAML config files. The main caveat
  with FormSpree is that it requires confirming the domain/email pair
  each time either changes, e.g. separately on the beta and www
  subdomains and separately for ACC and PEC.

* FormSpree redirects to the URL specified in the hidden input named
  next, which is currently set to "/thank-you/", so that page must be
  created and maintained in Contentful.

commit_list.message:
Work around IE bug impacting inline SVG height

By default, IE 10 and 11 render the interactive floor plan SVGs as
only ~150px tall, regardless of their width. Additional CSS
declarations don't seem to have any effect, so I resorted to setting
the height manually, via JS, based on the SVG's viewBox aspect ratio.

Note that the manual height doesn't update when the window is
resized, but I don't think that's worth the trouble.

commit_list.message:
Support option to render gallery as full-width images

Instead of thumbnails that open an image viewer. This lets content
editors use gallery blocks when they only need to add one or two
images to a page, which is preferable to using a text block because
it means the asset can be replaced in Contentful without needing to
also edit the text blocks that reference it.

commit_list.message:
Update floor plan map SVGs and match floor plan layout to spec

* All of the map SVGs are now stored in the repo, but the filename
  must be set as the title of each room's first content block in
  Contentful.

* .acc-floor-plan-specifications now shares the same flexbox layout
  as .acc-floor-plan-setups.

Consolidate menu rendering and add support for external links

commit_list.message:
Consolidate menu rendering and add support for external links

* Replaces the url_for tag with the more flexible find_document
  filter, opening the door for menus to reference page attributes
  other than url (e.g. to render page descriptions on the homepage).

* Consolidates all of the menu rendering (header, footer, homepage,
  and sidebar) into a single partial with options to customize the
  list and item classes.

* Contentful Menus may now include a new External Link content type,
  so we look for item.url before using doc.url.

* The button-grid styles have been tweaked slightly so that the grid
  itself can be a list (like the other menus), rather than a div.

commit_list.message:
Match color and type styles to latest specs

Removes some of the $acc- variables that weren't widely used, and
moves toward using USWDS variables instead of overriding tag styles
(such as for the header fonts).

I've also moved the page-title H1s, which were children of `usa-
grid`, into `usa-width-one-whole` within the page's main `usa-grid`,
and then within semantic `<header>` tags, so the H1 margins are no
longer removed by grid-related first-child/last-child rules.

commit_list.message:
Merge pull request #59 from cityofaustin/sidenav

Add sidenav and folder components
commit_list.repo_description: The Austin Convention Center (ACC) and Palmer Events Center (PEC) websites.

commit_list.message:
Implement responsive side navigation and add sprockets-commoner

Updates the sidenav component added in a previous commit to hide it
in a sliding panel on devices with smaller viewports (as determined
by the $large-screen breakpoint, which is where the 1/4 + 3/4 grid
breaks). The styling of the panel is heavily borrowed from the USWDS
equivalent, which is still used at the moment for the main nav.

This commit also includes the introduction of [sprockets-commoner], a
Sprockets extension maintained by Shopify that adds babel-powered
postprocessing of of CommonJS-style `require` statements. The sidenav
and folders components are now require'd in main.js and listen for
events through a main event delegate (an instance of [dom-delegate]
bound to `document`). Though they're not changed by this commit, the
Photoswipe and floor_plan.js will be able to adopt this pattern as
well.

The only gotcha I encountered was the need to narrow the files for
which sprockets-commoner tries to resolve `require`; by default, it
will resolve any JS file in the Sprockets paths, which ended up
causing problems when bundling the Tether lib. The solution was just
configuring commoner (via _plugins/hooks) to only process files in
_assets/javascripts and the specific npm modules that we want to
`require` (e.g. dom-delegate).

[sprockets-commoner]: https://github.com/Shopify/sprockets-commoner
[dom-delegate]: https://github.com/ftlabs/ftdomdelegate
commit_list.repo_description: The Austin Convention Center (ACC) and Palmer Events Center (PEC) websites.

commit_list.message:
Create reusable sidenav and folder components

The floor plan side navigation is now sorted by the page-level
priority attributes set in Contentful, and implements "folder"
expand/collapse behavior of sub-collections (e.g. Ballrooms and
Exhibit Halls).

I initially just extended the USWDS sidenav and accordion components,
but the styling and behavior we need differs significantly enough
that overwriting the USWDS defaults didn't really require any less
code and was more brittle and confusing than simply creating
components of our own, so I ended up doing that.

commit_list.message:
Convert floor plan maps to interactive SVGs

The floor plan maps now show a tooltip w/ the room name over each
room on over, and add a hover state and click handling if a matching
page is found in the floor plan sidenav.

* I couldn't find much documentation of this, but Chrome and Safari
  seem to disallow reading an externally-hosted SVG embedded with an
  <object> tag, throwing a same-origin error despite CORS headers. So
  instead of <object> tags, the level SVGs are now just pasted into
  the corresponding textBlocks. Not ideal, maybe, but unlike directly
  adding the SVGs here, it means we don't have to maintain a room-to-
  level mapping, since the page-to-text-block relationship is kept by
  Contentful.

* Embedding the SVG directly seems like it might also provide an
  advantage over <object> in terms of interoperability with third-
  party JS (i.e. tooltip libs). I went with Hubspot's Tooltip, which
  seems to work well. The documentation of Tooltip itself is sparse,
  but it has the same options as both the underlying dep (Drop), so
  it's fairly easy to configure.

commit_list.message:
Build and deploy PEC website from a separate Contentful space

Currently deploys to the beta.palmereventscenter.com S3 bucket.

Key changes:

* Site-specific config files in _config/ now extend the base
  _config.yml. This is a good place to put unique values, like the
  Google Analytics ID.

* Sass files can read values from the config file(s) with a new
  `config_value` function (mainly to allow us to give different
  values to variables depending on the site ID (acc or pec).

* Running `jekyll build` and `jekyll serve` now requires the --config
  argument, so I've abstracted them as `rake build:acc`, `rake
  build:pec`, or `rake build` (for both), and `foreman start acc`,
  `foreman start pec`, or `foreman start` (for both). Foreman allows
  you to run both sites at once, if you want. By default, it will
  bind the server to port 5000 for ACC and 5100 for PEC.

* Similarly, `rake contentful` now has `rake contentful:acc` and
  `rake contentful:pec` variants.

I did experiment with pushing the updated Contentful YAML files to
GitHub, which is something we considered early on, but I ultimately
decided against doing that, as it added a fair amount of conceptual
complexity that just didn't seem worth it.

commit_list.message:
Fix Flexbox-related bugs affecting Safari and Firefox

1. Safari doesn't play nicely with max-width (see
   [philipwalton/flexbugs #11]), so this switches to width.

2. Firefox doesn't render percentage bottom-margins on flex items,
   which is apparently not a bug but the correct behavior, so this
   switches to ems for the margins, and consequently calc for the
   widths.

Haven't yet tested this layout in IE so more fun may be yet to come.

[philipwalton/flexbugs #11]: https://github.com/philipwalton/flexbugs#11-min-and-max-size-declarations-are-ignored-when-wrapping-flex-items

commit_list.message:
Implement responsive image gallery and viewer (PhotoSwipe)

Gallery blocks now render as responsive grid of thumbnails cropped to
a 3:2 aspect ratio, and display in full (also responsive) sizes in
PhotoSwipe (photoswipe.com).

I picked PhotoSwipe from GitHub, where (by my estimation) it's the
most popular JS image viewer by far (12k+ stars). It has solid
documentation and an active community, and fairly extensive options
for customizing both the appearance and behavior. It's completely
markup-agnostic, which means we can use Schema.org's ImageGallery
markup.

The new JS file here is based on PhotoSwipe's example code, but
it doesn't bother with IE8 compatability and has a couple notable
differences:

* The responsive image sizing uses Contentful's Images API. Since
  PhotoSwipe needs the dimensions among its options, we calculate
  them based on the original image's dimensions, which are output by
  the new GalleryBlockMapper and rendered as data- attributes.

* It uses Contentful IDs for the gallery ID and picture ID that
  PhotoSwipe sets in the URL hash, which means that permalinks should
  still work regardless of the order of gallery blocks and images
  within them.

The responsive thumbnail grid uses flexbox and shows either 2 or 3
images per row depending on the viewport. I spent a lot of time
trying different flexbox options; my original hope was to crop the
thumbnails in CSS so that we could enable PhotoSwipe's nice
transition animation using the uncropped thumbnail. In theory, we'd
want to say that a thumbnail is 33% wide and has a height of 2/3rds
of that, hiding the overflow, but percentage heights are sort of a
joke; CSS ignores them unless the parent has a fixed height.

Thus flexbox loves to render each row at the height of the tallest
thumbnail. I *could* set a best-guess max-height in pixels, but that
changes the aspect ratio of the thumbnails as the viewport scales,
and the transition animation looks almost as janky as starting with a
pre-cropped thumbnail. I eventually just gave up, cropped the
thumbnails via the Contentful API, and disabled the animation.

The flexbox styles are fairly straightforward, the only maybe-unusual
part is the nth-of-type declarations. Flexbox's justify-content rule
doesn't work well if rows don't have the same number of items, so
those are needed to have edge-to-edge rows with the last row aligned
left.

The only additional gallery feature that I think we might want to add
would be limiting the number of thumbnails displayed, and having a
"View All" button open PhotoSwipe if there are more than the limit.
Whether that makes sense depends a lot on how many photos there end
up being, so we can wait and add it later.

commit_list.message:
Revise custom template pattern and allow Pages to extend Sections

* The previous implementation of custom templates looked for a file
  in _custom with a matching contentful_id in its frontmatter, which
  was a somewhat brittle and unintuitive process; the new way matches
  files from _templates based on their URL, or (by default) their
  relative path within _templates. A page with the URL /calendar/
  looks for a file at _templates/calendar.html.

* The generator now compares each Page's URL to a section's existing
  docs and extends an existing doc if found. In practice, this means
  that the section layout now has access to Page model attributes IFF
  there is a Page with the same (parent) section and slug as the
  given Section.

We've also lately decided to use regular Pages and Sections to
organize floor plans rather than a specific Room model, so this
commit removes what was specific to that model.

we're bundling from source, this includes the bundled/minified JS,
because our build process doesn't currently support commonJS modules.

commit_list.message:
Add generator to scaffold month-by-month calendar pages

A new CalendarGenerator creates pages for each month between the
first and last month found in the calendar data imported from Socrata
(including, right now, months that don't have any events). Events
that span the end of a month also appear on the next month's page.

The month pages render from a new "month" layout, while the main
/calendar/ page is now a Section in Contentful, with a custom
template in _custom (depending on the final design, it may end up
making more sense to simply add logic in the section layout, instead
of using an entirely custom layout, but that's TBD).

Breadcrumbs work on Calendar pages, with a minimal amount of
supporting logic now shared in a "Helpers" module between the
Contentful and Calendar generators.

Additional logic around filtering past events and so on remains TBD.

Create a url_for tag to match Contentful objects to document URLs

commit_list.message:
Refactor header and footer selectors

Continuing to move toward some Sass style and naming conventions:

* Using project-prefixed selectors alongside framework selectors
  (e.g. both `usa-nav` and `acc-nav`), mainly to indicate in markup
  what which elements we're customizing in our own Sass, vs which are
  only inheriting from USWDS.

  The main caveat to this approach seems to be having to contend, in
  some situations, with selector precedence, when a more specific
  USWDS overrule is overriding an .acc- style. Most of the time, the
  solution will probably be adding more .acc selectors until their
  speficity equals or outweighs USWDS. We'll see how it goes.

* Not nesting selectors, mostly. Nesting makes sense for pseudo-
  selectors and very simple one-offs, but overuse can easily end
  up discouraging appropriate modular, component-based design.

  http://markdotto.com/2015/07/20/css-nesting/

commit_list.message:
Support nested sections and track breadcrumbs in generator

Contentful sections now include an optional parentSection attribute,
allowing us to create nested section structures. (The use case for
ACC is a Services parent section of the Event and Exhibitor Services
sections.)

The generator's generate_section method will now call itself
recursively if parentSection is set (and because this effectively
induces duplicate calls, it's now called find_or_generate_section,
and uses an instance cache for lookups of previously-generated
sections).

The main gotcha here was permalinks: setting 'permalink' in
generate_page isn't sufficient to generate accurate URLs for pages in
nested sections, because Jekyll's :collection URL placeholder simply
renders the collection label (which can't contain slashes). Instead,
the generator now sets the 'permalink' attribute on each Collection's
metadata, which Jekyll then uses as the template to generate each
child document's URL.

find_or_generate_section also now manually sets each section page's
layout, since nested sections don't automatically inherit the
sections layout set in _config.yml's defaults. Given the current
implementation, all section pages must share the same layout.

Lastly, the generator now adds a 'breadcrumbs' attribute to each
generated page, which includes an ordered array of the titles and
URLs of the page's parent section(s), if any. The last breadcrumb
corresponds to the page itself.

commit_list.message:
Switch to jekyll-assets pipeline with npm-managed uswds

The primary motive for switching to a proper asset pipeline beyond
Jekyll's default support for Sass is being able to bundle USWDS from
source, so that we can override built-in variables including sizing,
spacing, and colors. (This is the recommended way to customize USWDS
per standards.usa.gov.) We will also of course take advantage of
jekyll-assets & Sprockets' other features, including asset hashing
for cache-busting and so on.

(NPM is the only package manager 18F officially supports for USWDS,
but that didn't prove to be a problem; getting Sprockets to play
nicely with node_modules mainly just required a couple of link_tree
directives to declare dependencies on the images and fonts.)

Probably the biggest downside to compiling USWDS ourselves is the
performance hit, especially because Sass's @import statement is
perhaps the slowest single part of a Sprockets process. I've tried to
minimize the cost by importing uswds in a separate file (uswds.scss),
and then using Sprocket's `require`, rather than import, to include
it in main.scss—using `require` means Sprockets will cache the
compiled version of uswds.scss. The caveat is that `require`, unlike
@import, doesn't share scope (variables and functions), so we may
need a higher-level variable file if we need to share some things
between our Sass and USWDS.

In general, as well, it's my understanding that we should aim to
minimize and localize imports of dependencies (like Bourbon
functions) to the specific scss files that need them, and then
(again) use Sprocket's `require` instead of @import—but we can do
some trial and error to see how that plays out in day-to-day use.

Finally, I'll add that I did get about halfway down the road of using
Webpack for this instead of jekll-assets/Sprockets. The Webpack
documentation leaves something to be desired, but Webpack itself
worked well, and certainly offered more granular control than
Sprockets (some might say too granular). That said, the sheer amount
of configuration required and the lack of plug-and-play integration
with a Ruby/Jekyll process (e.g. for referencing compiled/hashed
assets) eventually seemed like too high a hurdle to bother jumping
for this project.

commit_list.message:
Add README, including Contentful-related developer usage docs

The README provides a quick explanation the project to anyone who
might find it on a GitHub, and more in-depth usage instructions to
developers working on the project.

I decided while writing it to add _data/contentful to the .gitignore,
instead of committing the YAML files it contains to master; that
change has since been committed to master. My thinking is that
committing changes to the data file in our topic branches could easily
become noisy and distracting, and even potentially introduce
cumbersome merge conflicts. The downside to _not_ committing it is
that every developer on the project currently needs Contentful API
keys to sync the updated data; especially once the data stabilizes
(i.e. by the time the new website launches), that might not be ideal.
At that point, our continuous deployment process could
push changes to the data file to a non-master branch, and we could
replace `jekyll contentful` with a command to simply pull changes from
that branch, no keys required.

The new README includes some inline TODO comments about what's still
left to add.

commit_list.message:
Create Jekyll plugin to generate pages from Contentful data

The jekyll-contentful-data-import gem maintained by Contentful does
what it says on the tin: it fetches data from Contentful's Content
Delivery API and puts it in a YAML file in the _data folder. Jekyll
loads that data file automatically, but everything else is up to us;
we get to tell Jekyll how to translate our data into a site.

I've done that by creating a generator (one of Jekyll's plugin types)
that maps the Sections and Pages of our Contentful content model to
what Jekyll calls Collections and Documents. By default, these render
into standard layouts (e.g. _layouts/section and _layouts/page), but
I've also made sure our generated collections can be configured via
the defaults hash defined in _config.yml (that's the main advantage
of a Jekyll::Document over a Jekyll::Page).

This commit also introduces the "custom" collection, which allows us
to associate a specific template with the Contentful ID of any Page or
Section, and thus extend the default templates with one-off
modifications or features. I'm not totally sure we'll need this in the
long run, but it could be useful during prototyping.

The last change in here renders the header menu from a menu entry
defined in Contentful. It's very basic right now (string matching
on the menu name), and I'm a bit undecided about whether it should
stay that way.

I'll be writing developer-oriented usage documentation that explains
how to render Contentful data in templates, how to customize
collections, and so forth, but you can get a head start by just
checking out the templates in this diff.

commit_list.message:
Update README with workflow to change Contentful content model

Outlined the basic procedure to spin up dev spaces from production
data, make content model changes, and then import those changes back
to the production spaces. The workflow relies on Contentful's export
and import tools, which have replaced the contentful-space-sync tool
that was previously referenced in the README.

Some of the documentation related to the import tool suggests that it
only works on "new and empty spaces." I'm not sure if that applies
when you're importing content, or if it's just a recommendation, but I
used the tool to import --content-model-only changes to existing
spaces and it seemed to work just fine.
commit_list.repo_description: The Austin Convention Center (ACC) and Palmer Events Center (PEC) websites.

commit_list.message:
Implement galleryImage model to support rich text captions

The gallery block previously included direct links to assets, which
was enough to show basic plain text captions in the PhotoSwipe viewer,
but it otherwise limited options to customize metadata associated with
gallery images, including the possibility of having rich captions.

The Convention Center's upcoming Art Collection page will need to
render a gallery with captions that are both rich text, with links to
artist detail pages, and inline, rather than only in the PhotoSwipe
viewer.

This commit introduces support for those options, through a new
showCaptions boolean on the galleryBlock model, and by moving from
direct links to assets to a galleryImage model with a rich text
(Markdown) caption field.

It also includes a Rake task to migrate the gallery assets from the
existing images field to the new galleryImages field and content type.
This is run (after the necessary content model changes have been made
in Contentful) via

```
CONTENTFUL_SPACE_ID=*** rake -f lib/tasks/migrate_gallery_images.rake
```
